channel.title: RSS Aggregator Feed
channel.description: An aggregated feed of Technology-related news

item.title: FCC calls on broadcasters to air ‘pro-America content’ for the country’s 250th anniversary
item.description: Federal Communications Commission Chair Brendan Carr is urging broadcasters to air "patriotic, pro-America content" in celebration of the US's 250th anniversary. The initiative, called the "Pledge America Campaign," encourages broadcasters to run public service announcements, short segments, or specials to promote "civic education, inspiring local stories, and American history." Carr says broadcasters can "voluntarily choose […]...

item.title: InScope nabs $14.5M to solve the pain of financial reporting
item.description: The startup, founded by accountants who worked at Flexport, Miro, Hopin and Thrive Global, automates the difficulties of prepping financial statements.

item.title: Wunmi Mosaku on the Most Surprising Moments in ‘Sinners’
item.description: The Oscar nominee praises the 'perfect script' that still brought unexpected moments to the screen.

item.title: Yes, Gravity Made These Space Snowmen. No, It’s Not That Simple
item.description: Astronomers had decent guesses about how these peanut-shaped asteroids formed but couldn’t get the physics to work—until now.

item.title: Elon Musk’s Dusty Texas Town Needs Some Law and Order
item.description: Starbase, Texas, has grown to over 580 people.

item.title: OpenAI Might Be Making a Smart Speaker That No One Asked for
item.description: Rejoice: a smart speaker that can... identify objects on a table.

item.title: Tunic publisher claims TikTok ran 'racist, sexist' AI ads for one of its games without its knowledge
item.description: Indie publisher and developer Finji has accused TikTok of using generative AI to alter the ads for its games on the platform without its knowledge or permission. Finji, which published indie darlings like Night in the Woods and Tunic, said it only became aware of the seemingly modified ads after being alerted to them by followers of its official TikTok account. As reported by IGN, Finji alleges that one ad that went out on the platform was modified so it displayed a "racist, sexualized" representation of a character from one of its games. While it does advertise on TikTok, it told IGN that it ...

item.title: It’s Not Just Pugs—New Study IDs the Dog Breeds at High Risk of Breathing Issues
item.description: Bulldogs and pugs are far from the only dogs frequently suffering from breathing problems, new research shows.

item.title: Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 7 vs OnePlus Open : comment choisir le meilleur smartphone pliant au format fold ?
item.description: Samsung reste le leader incontesté du marché des smartphones pliants, mais cela ne devrait pas occulter qu'il existe bel et bien une concurrence. Le OnePlus Open peut-il se défendre contre le dernier-né du géant sud-coréen ?

item.title: Yes, everyone can be creative
item.description: Here’s how to demystify innovation and unlock it in your team We have a complicated relationship with creativity. Intuitively, we understand its value—the ability to produce new ideas and novel innovation. Instinctively, we know that it presents opportunities for marketplace advancements. When we think of some of the most revered organizations in modern times, like the Apple’s and Disney’s of the world, we point to their creative contributions and their impact. However, although most companies revere organizations with a creative culture, there is a deep-seated misnomer that some companies are...

item.title: AMC is pulling this AI-generated film from theaters after social media outcry over ‘hot garbage’
item.description: An internet outcry resulted in a rare victory for anti-AI advocates, who threatened to boycott over showings of the AI short. When word started circling that AMC Theaters was screening an AI-generated short film, the internet’s cinephiles took it personally.

item.title: Metadata Exposes Authors of ICE’s ‘Mega’ Detention Center Plans
item.description: Comments and other data left on a PDF detailing Homeland Security’s proposal to build “mega” detention and processing centers reveal the personnel involved in its creation.

item.title: Great news for xAI: Grok is now pretty good at answering questions about Baldur’s Gate
item.description: A new report from Business Insider reveals that high-level engineers at xAI were pulled off other projects to make sure Grok could answer detailed questions about the video game "Baldur's Gate."

item.title: All the Toys From ‘The Mandalorian and Grogu’ We Now Want, But Probably Won’t Get
item.description: After the release of the new 'Star Wars' trailer, we're craving even more than the merch that has already been released.

item.title: Top Android AI photo and video editor exposes nearly two million user images and videos
item.description: A misconfigured database holding millions of images and videos was found online, and promptly secured.

item.title: The Best Chairs and Desks From Branch Are On Sale (We've Tested Them All)
item.description: Branch makes excellent office essentials, and our top picks are discounted.

item.title: Trump Mobile is just Liberty Mobile in gold foil
item.description: Where's the Trump phone? We're going to keep talking about it every week. This week, we explain how the presidential phone company connects to an older company that's really running the show. We've long known that Trump Mobile was linked to Liberty Mobile, a carrier that's traded for years using freedom-themed branding to sell cheap […]

item.title: This budget laptop deal is absurd: You're basically buying Windows 11 Pro and Microsoft Office for $279, and getting a 32GB RAM 15.6-inch machine for free
item.description: Better-than-half-price 15.6-inch Bitecool laptop comes with 32GB of RAM, Windows 11 Pro, and Microsoft Office for just $279.

item.title: Why staying solo is a strategic decision
item.description: Not all business have to staff up to succeed At one point in my life, I managed a team of seven. My days consisted of 1:1 calls, performance reviews, and running interference between the team, other departments, and customers.

item.title: Beware the business school case study: the cautionary tale of Southwest Airlines
item.description: Case studies capture what worked at a particular moment. That doesn’t mean it will work again The venerable business case study method got its start in 1921 at the Harvard Business School. The method became standard at the school throughout the 1920’s and since then Harvard has a near-monopoly grip on the business, selling its cases to over 4,000 rival schools. ...

item.title: Everything is gambling now: the latest news on prediction markets like Polymarket and Kalshi
item.description: Prediction markets will let you bet on just about anything, from how many tweets Elon Musk will post this week to the next president of the United States, with predictions sometimes showing shockingly (or suspiciously) spot-on accuracy. Polymarket’s CEO Shayne Copland has even claimed that prediction markets are “the most accurate thing we have as […]...

item.title: New Technique for 3D Printing Artificial Muscle Paves the Way for More Freaky Robots
item.description: Never enough robots!

item.title: This might be the best RTX 5060 laptop deal for photo and video editing right now — color-accurate HP Omen 14 packs a Core Ultra 7 and 3K OLED display for under $1300
item.description: Massive $700 discount drops HP Omen Transcend with Core Ultra 7 and RTX 5060 to $1300 — a fantastic deal for creative and professional users.

item.title: OpenAI : et si le premier appareil IA avec Jony Ive était… une enceinte connectée ?
item.description: C'est décidément le feuilleton qui tient toute la Silicon Valley en haleine : quel sera le premier appareil d'OpenAI ? Tout ou presque y est passé, des écouteurs au badge, en passant pourquoi pas par le stylo. Mais ce produit conçu avec Jony Ive pourrait être finalement assez banal, à en croire une nouvelle rumeur crédible.

item.title: Ukrainian man jailed for identity theft that helped North Koreans get jobs at US companies
item.description: A Ukrainian man has been sentenced for helping North Koreans gain fraudulent employment at dozens of U.S. companies and funnel that money back to the regime to fund its nuclear weapons program.
